Introduction

library(tidyverse)

I want to write a script here to be able to recursively obtain all the dataset metadata in the GEO database for the childhood dementias.

The tricky thing will be the keywords here, might use the childhood dementia knowledge-base as inspiration.

Key words

I went to the CDI knowledgebase and downloaded a spreadsheet of “diseases”. Below is a preview of this spreadsheet.

MPS III (Sanfilippo syndrome) ORPHA:581 NA N currently untreatable Sanfilippo syndrome, MPS 3, MPS III, Sanfilippo disease Autosomal recessive Mucopolysaccharidoses Lysosomal disease,Inborn errors of metabolism Mucopolysaccharidosis type III (MPS III, Sanfilippo syndrome) is a lysosomal storage disease belonging to the group of mucopolysaccharidoses and characterised by severe and rapid intellectual deterioration. There are 4 types, each due to the deficiency of a different enzyme. Attenuated forms with milder symptoms and slower progression exist. 2.30 Typically, disease onset is before ten years of age. For the severe phenotype (more common) symptoms can present around 2 years, while age of onset for the attenuated form is around 4 years of age. A weighted average of the age of onset for the subtypes was used |Wagner VF, Northrup H. Mucopolysaccharidosis Type III. 2019 Sep 19. MPS IIIB (Sanfilippo syndrome type B) ORPHA:79270 OMIM:252920 Y currently untreatable Mucopolysaccharidosis type IIIB , MPS 3B, MPS IIIB, Sanfilippo disease type 3B Autosomal recessive Mucopolysaccharidoses Lysosomal disease,Inborn errors of metabolism This is a subtype of the entry “Mucopolysaccharidosis type III”. A rare autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease caused by deficiency of the enzyme N-acetyl-alpha-D-glucosaminidase. It is characterised by behavioural changes, sleep disturbances, and intellectual deterioration. NA In the registry of the Dutch diagnostic centers, records from 52 patients with MPS IIIB from 32 families, onset was at a median of 4 years (range 1–10 years) but this study contained a large number of attenuated patients. Valstar MJ, Bruggenwirth HT, Olmer R, et al. Mucopolysaccharidosis type IIIB may predominantly present with an attenuated clinical phenotype. J Inherit Metab Dis. 2010;33(6):759-767. doi:10.1007/s10545-010-9199-y 3.0

The average age at diagnosis was 36 months (median, 35 months) in an analysis of two international natural history studies studies (n=65) (Okur et al., 2022).

In a Dutch study (Valstar et al., 2010) the definitive diagnosis of MPS IIIB in the index patients was made at a median age of 13 years (range 1–66 years).

In Chin and Fuller 10 Australian MPSIIIb patients were diagnosed at a median age of 4.5 (range 1.4-39.6).

For patients with an attenuated form, diagnosis may be as late as adulthood; in one Dutch study, which included 33 attenuated MPS IIIB patients, the median age at diagnosis was 28 years (Valstar et al., 2010)

MPS IIIC (Sanfilippo syndrome type C) ORPHA:79271 OMIM:252930 Y currently untreatable Mucopolysaccharidosis type IIIC , MPS 3C, MPS IIIC, Sanfilippo disease type 3C Autosomal recessive Mucopolysaccharidoses Lysosomal disease,Inborn errors of metabolism This is a subtype of the entry “MPS III (Sanfilippo syndrome)”. MPS IIIC is a rare autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease caused by deficiency of the enzyme acetyl-CoA:alpha-glucosaminide acetyltransferase. It is characterised by behavioural changes, sleep disturbances, and intellectual deterioration. 3.50 In one study, the first clinical signs of MPS IIIC were noted between 1-6 years (with an average mean of 3.5 years). 29 Dutch MPS IIIC patients. Ruijter GJ, Valstar MJ, van de Kamp JM, van der Helm RM, Durand S, van Diggelen OP, Wevers RA, Poorthuis BJ, Pshezhetsky AV, Wijburg FA. PMID: 18024218. 4.5 In Australia, the age of diagnosis ranges from 0.7-8.0, with a median age of 2.3 (Chin and Fuller, 2021). Misdiagnosis is common, especially in the early stages of the disease. Common misdiagnoses include autism, ADHD, and idiopathic developmental delay. Diagnosis can vary - in one study of living and deceased patients, the age of definitive MPS IIIC diagnosis for 11 patients was between the ages of 2 and 7 with a mean of 4.5 years. The alternative_names column looks useful - carries all the names for each disease.

I need to break this up into smaller fragments to be able to search this in R. rentrez will throw an error if I try searching all at once.

# split the multiple names within each disease
cd.keywords <- cdi_diseases$alternative_names %>% na.omit() %>% 
  str_split(pattern = ", ", ) %>% 
  unlist(use.names = F) %>% 
  str_split(pattern = "; ") %>% 
  unlist(use.names = F) %>% 
  unique

the cd keywords (600 words/terms) were exported for manual curation, then reimported. some of the abbreviations will not be totally useful and will pull out random stuff.

cd.keywords %>% 
  write.csv("output/cdi_keywords.csv")

cd.keywords <- 
  read.csv("output/cdi_keywords.csv", blank.lines.skip = TRUE)$x


# create a list which has 12 keywords per list element. 
cd.keywords.searchterm <- cd.keywords %>% 
  split(ceiling(seq_along(cd.keywords) / 5)) %>% # split the list
  lapply(function(x) {
    paste(x, "OR ") # add an OR for searching. 
  }) %>% 
  lapply(function(x) {
    x %>% 
      str_flatten() %>% # convert to a single vector
      str_sub(end = -5) # remove the last "OR"
  })

all keywords.

# this takes a while
# search the GEO db for all the childhood dementia search terms. 
record.summaries.all <- cd.keywords.searchterm %>% 
  lapply(function(x) {
    search_results <- entrez_search(db = "gds", term = x)
    geo_accessions <- search_results$ids
    record_summaries <- lapply(geo_accessions, 
                               function(id) entrez_summary(db = "gds", id = id)
    )
})

# convert to a tibble
all.res.tibble <- record.summaries.all %>% 
  lapply(function(rs) {
    lapply(rs, function(x) 
      {
    tibble(
      accession = x$accession,    # GEO accession number
      species = x$taxon, 
      type = x$gdstype %>% unlist, # type of exp
      title = x$title,            # Title of the dataset
      summary = x$summary,         # Summary/description
      nsamples = x$samples %>% nrow
    )
    })
  }) %>% 
  bind_rows()

I then searched all the keywords recursively. The GEO database (GDS) was searched with the package rentrez for all the search terms from the “alternative names” column fron the CDI KB. This returned 1606 datasets. These are found in the table below. you can search keywords in the search box.

# display as a DT table. 
all.res.tibble %>% 
  datatable(
    class = 'cell-border stripe', 
    filter = "top",
    caption = 'Table 1: childhood dementia datasets in GEO database.'
  )

export data

A spreadsheet was generated for manual curation of irrelevant datasets. This can be downloaded from the github repo associated with this webpage.

# export the results for manual curation
record.summaries.all %>% 
  lapply(function(rs) {
    lapply(rs, function(x) 
      {
    tibble(
      accession = x$accession,    # GEO accession number
      species = x$taxon,
      type = x$gdstype %>% unlist, # type of exp
      title = x$title,            # Title of the dataset
      summary = x$summary,         # Summary/description
      nsamples = x$samples %>% nrow
    )
    })
  }) %>% 
  bind_rows() %>% 
  write_excel_csv("output/20241205 childhood dementia GEOdb.csv")
